Virtually every one of the 16,500 students in
thirty-seven of the county’s elementary and sec¬
ondary schools receives at least one period of tele¬
vised instruction daily. The Washington County
ETV system has 74.3 miles of coaxial cable reach¬
ing into schools ranging from the ultra-modern
1,500-pupil North Hagerstown High School to the
two-room, forty-five-pupil school in rural Beaver
Creek. Since it is a closed-circuit system, more
than one course at a time can be telecast. The
system has six channels and telecasts a total of
125 lessons a week in all twelve grades and in
all major subjects.
But with regard to the goals, operations, and
effects of televised instruction, the Washington
County project is similar to other school systems
in that it closely coordinates ETV with classroom
teaching.
The only course in which instruction is entirely
televised is “Math for Mathematicians,” which
deals with the elements of calculus, analytical
geometry, and other college-level mathematics.
The course is an advanced, difficult elective in
which only sixty-five students in four high schools
in the county were enrolled in the 1959-60 school
year. In outlying Hancock High School, only
three students were enrolled; without television,
no single school could likely spare a teacher for
such a small number of students. In most of the
classrooms where the course is televised, no teach¬
ers are present. It is broadcast Monday, Wednes¬
day, and Friday. On Tuesday and Thursday, the
teacher visits the high schools in rotation for
review, testing, and discussion with students en¬
rolled in the course.
The Hagerstown project headquarters, Television
Center, began in a corrugated metal shed and
now has five studios, offices for twenty-six tele¬
vision teachers and supervisors, an art studio, and
rooms for film storage and equipment —14,000
square feet in all. The atmosphere is a blend of
a busy broadcasting center and an academic set¬
ting. Charts, maps, textbooks, laboratory equip¬
ment, and blackboards are arrayed among daz¬
zling klieg lights and electronic gear. Tacked on
a wall of a cubicle housing the videotape machine,
